diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially leading to a wide range of symptoms including fatigue, difficulty focusing, and fertility issues.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). Diabetes can lead to atherosclerosis and other health complications if not managed properly.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms can include infertility, weight gain, and potentially increased risk of atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. Can affect concentration and sleep patterns.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complicated disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Chemical sensitivities and difficulty focusing are common complaints.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity (MCS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which exposure to everyday chemicals and pollutants causes symptoms like headaches, fatigue, and dizziness.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep, causing fragmented sleep and a range of complications including difficulty focusing.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: Also known as high blood pressure, it can be linked to atherosclerosis and increased risks of both heart diseases and infertility.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: Chronic stress can lead to a variety of symptoms including difficulty concentrating, sleep issues, and may contribute to the development of atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A cluster of conditions that occur together, increasing your risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. These conditions can include increased blood pressure, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol levels.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It may lead to symptoms like dysgeusia, joint pain, and irritability, although it's not directly associated with endometriosis or bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing chronic inflammation of the joints, often leading to joint pain and could be associated with other systemic symptoms of inflammation that might loosely relate to irritability or dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by joint pain. Though not directly linked to dysgeusia, chronic inflammation could potentially contribute to systemic symptoms like irritability.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It can cause dysgeusia due to dry mouth and systemic symptoms like joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus is a chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body, including joints. It's known for affecting skin, joints, and internal organs, potentially contributing to irritability and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. It can be associated with joint pains and is known for affecting mood, potentially leading to irritability.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: While typically known for causing painful periods, endometriosis can lead to systemic symptoms like fatigue and chronic pain, which may contribute to a state of irritability, though it is less associated with dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: While primarily affecting the digestive system, GERD can cause dysgeusia or an altered taste in the mouth. Chronic discomfort from GERD might also contribute to irritability.

diagnoses.name: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: Though primarily affecting the lungs and causing conditions like bronchitis, COPD can lead to systemic issues like chronic pain, fatigue, and potentially dysgeusia due to medication side effects or co-morbid conditions.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: Depression is a mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. It can manifest physically, contributing to symptoms like joint pain, and can directly cause or exacerbate irritability.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can explain hypermobility and potentially contribute to cyst formation.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells inappropriately release chemical mediators, leading to a range of chronic symptoms. It could indirectly explain basophilia due to the inflammatory process, and is also associated with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS).

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that most commonly affects older adults. Basophilia and lymphadenopathy are potential symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy and cysts in various organs.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that affects connective tissue — the fibers that support and anchor your organs and other structures in your body. It is known to cause hypermobility among other cardiovascular, eye, and skeletal abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also lead to lymphadenopathy and has been associated with cyst formation in glands.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of the lymphatic system, which is part of the immune system. It can lead to lymphadenopathy and has been associated indirectly with symptoms like basophilia.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. It can also cause an increase in white blood cells, including basophils, and is sometimes associated with lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A progressive, genetic disease that causes persistent lung infections and limits the ability to breathe over time. It is primarily known for affecting the lungs but can also lead to the development of cysts in other parts of the body, including the pancreas.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can lead to a wide range of symptoms, varying from cardiac, joint, and neurological symptoms to conditions like POTS.

diagnoses: Secondary Hyperparathyroidism (due to chronic kidney disease)

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, potentially causing symptoms such as lymphadenitis due to secondary infections, and skin conditions like folliculitis. Eosinophilia may also be observed in some HIV-infected individuals.

diagnoses.name: Dermatitis herpetiformis
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition presenting with blisters, often associated with gluten sensitivity, which can lead to eosinophilia. Folliculitis can be a secondary infection.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by very high levels of eosinophils in the body, leading to organ damage and potentially affecting the skin, manifesting as folliculitis or other skin conditions.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system that can cause lymphadenitis as it affects lymph nodes. It's also associated with chronic pain, and eosinophilia can occur in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis can cause chronic back pain, lymphadenitis, folliculitis due to skin involvement, and eosinophilia as part of the broader immune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that often affects the lymph nodes (lymphadenitis) and lungs, but can also lead to skin manifestations including folliculitis and chronic pain syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can cause lymphadenitis, with the potential for chronic pain due to bone involvement (Pott's disease) and eosinophilia in rare cases.

diagnoses.name: Parasitic Infections
diagnoses.description: Infections like schistosomiasis can cause eosinophilia and lymphadenitis. Folliculitis can occur due to secondary bacterial infections.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reactions
diagnoses.description: Certain medications can cause eosinophilia and induce a variety of skin reactions that mimic folliculitis. Drug-induced lymphadenitis is also possible.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to a substance in contact with the skin, leading to folliculitis-like lesions, possibly associated with eosinophilia. Chronic pain could be a secondary effect due to the inflammation.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation with gastroesophageal reflux

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Common Cold or Upper Respiratory Infection
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (with acute cutaneous lupus)
Foreign body aspiration in the respiratory tract
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by pruritus and angioedema, often with unknown cause, lasting more than six weeks.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder affecting the large intestine, causing symptoms like cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, and constipation.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food, causing various symptoms, including diarrhea, rhinorrhea, and sometimes angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause angioedema, diarrhea, and various other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Gastrointestinal Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders characterized by elevated levels of eosinophils in the gastrointestinal tract, causing symptoms like diarrhea and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: Swelling deep in the skin, often accompanied by hives, which may also lead to breathing difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing episodes of severe swelling in various parts of the body, including the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Neurogenic Bladder
diagnoses.description: A condition of the bladder that results from an injury or illness affecting the nervous system, potentially leading to incontinence.

diagnoses: Foreign body in the nasal passage

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that's preceded or accompanied by sensory disturbances called an aura, which may include flashes of light, blind spots, or other vision changes or tingling in your hand or face.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a dull, aching pain and tightness in the forehead, scalp, or neck. It's often associated with stress but lacks the features of migraine, such as nausea and photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those you'd get in a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage. They're caused by a temporary decrease in blood supply to part of the brain, which may cause symptoms such as numbness and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS blocks messages between your brain and your body, leading to symptoms such as numbness, weakness, imbalance, or trouble walking.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: A condition that produces severe headaches much more painful but typically shorter than migraines. Often you'll feel the headaches on one side of the head, and they may be associated with watery eyes, nasal congestion, or swelling around the eyes on the affected side.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal mass of cells that forms in the brain. Depending on the location, they can cause headaches, nausea, seizures, weakness, or numbness and changes in personality, mood, mental capacity, and concentration.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that causes severe dizziness (vertigo), ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness or congestion in the ear. It isn't directly associated with headache, but the distress and fatigue it causes can contribute to headache disorders.

diagnoses.name: Intracranial Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Occurs when blood suddenly bursts into brain tissue, causing damage to the brain. Symptoms can include a sudden, severe headache, weakness, numbness, or increased sensitivity to light, and nausea or vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent headaches that are moderate to severe. Symptoms may include phonophobia, nausea, and light sensitivity. Some migraines are preceded by sensory warning symptoms or signs.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include weakness, difficulty speaking, and numbness, particularly on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma)
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor that develops on the balance and hearing nerves leading from your inner ear to the brain. Symptoms can include hearing loss and imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from not enough vitamin B12 which can lead to neurological issues such as numbness and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to symptoms like weakness and tingling in your extremities. It can progress to paralysis and is considered a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Its symptoms may vary greatly and include numbness, weakness, hearing loss, and other neurological deficits depending on the tumor’s location and size.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur if you have diabetes. High blood sugar can injure nerves throughout your body. Diabetic neuropathy most often damages nerves in your legs and feet and may lead to numbness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early signs may include fatigue, headache, fever, and skin rash. If untreated, it can spread to the joints, heart, and the nervous system, causing more severe symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In some cases, it may cause tinnitus, a constant ringing in the ear, alongside progressive hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, kidneys, and hematologic system, characterised by symptoms like malar rash and can include nasal ulcers and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing chronic inflammation of the joints and other parts of the body, which can occasionally present with systemic features like rheumatoid nodules and skin ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by changes in the skin, blood vessels, muscles, and internal organs. Skin changes include telangiectasias and can rarely have ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. It affects collagen vessels in the skin and muscles, and can lead to symptoms such as telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that has features of three other connective tissue diseases—lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis/dermatomyositis, including skin manifestations and potentially hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener's)
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys. It can present with nasal ulcers and systemic effects including anemia.

diagnoses.name: Polychondritis
diagnoses.description: An episodic and progressive inflammatory disorder of the cartilage and tissues of the body, showing a variety of symptoms including nose cartilage inflammation which might cause nasal ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can include mouth and genital ulcers, and skin problems such as acne-like sores.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the body’s blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. Some forms can lead to hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that damages your immune system. Over time, it can lead to AIDS and can cause a wide range of symptoms, including anemia and rare reports of skin manifestations.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
